prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: I ZW 1
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Resolving out the CO(1-0) emission in I ZW 1.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: The line width (FWHM) of I ZW 1 is 370 km/s, we will further smooth the channel width to 40 km/s.

We expect to resolve out the CO(1-0) emission in I ZW 1. Previous PdBI observations show that the molecular gas of IR QSOs is concentrated in the nuclear 1 kpc region. The physical scale of 1 arcsecond is 1.2 kpc for I ZW 1, and we request an angular resolution of 0.4 arcsecond for resolving.

The CO(1-0) peak flux density of I ZW 1 measured with the IRAM 30m is 90 mJy. Allowing for a small fraction (~30%) of extended emission that might be missed by long baseline observations, we need to achieve an RMS of ~1.26 mJy/beam that will ensure a S/N~10 at the peak of CO line in the assumption that CO emitting region extend to ~5 beams. The CO(1-0) line width (FWHM) of I ZW 1 is 370 km/s, and we use a bandwidth of 40 km/s for sensitivity calculation.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: IRAS 06269-0543
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Resolving out the CO(1-0) emission in IRAS 06269-0543

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: The line width (FWHM) of IRAS 06269-0543 is 260 km/s, we will further smooth the channel width to 40 km/s.

We expect to resolve out the CO(1-0) emission in IRAS 06269-0543. Previous PdBI observations show that the molecular gas of IR QSOs is concentrated in the nuclear 1 kpc region. The physical scale of 1 arcsecond is 2.1 kpc for IRAS 06269-0543, and we request an angular resolution of 0.4 arcsecond for resolving.

The CO(1-0) peak flux density of IRAS 06269-0543 measured with the IRAM 30m is 42 mJy. Allowing for a small fraction (~30%) of extended emission that might be missed by long baseline observations, we need to achieve an RMS of ~0.6 mJy/beam that will ensure a S/N~10 at the peak of CO line in the assumption that CO emitting region extend to ~5 beams. The CO(1-0) line width (FWHM) of IRAS 06269-0543 is 260 km/s, and we use a bandwidth of 40 km/s for sensitivity calculation.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: IRAS F11119+3257
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Resolving out the CO(1-0) emission in IRAS F11119+3257

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: The line width (FWHM) of IRAS F11119+3257 is 290 km/s, we will further smooth the channel width to 50 km/s.

We expect to resolve out the CO(1-0) emission in IRAS F11119+3257. Previous PdBI observations show that the molecular gas of IR QSOs concentrate in the nuclear 1 kpc region. The physical scale of 1 arcsecond is 3.2 kpc for IRAS F11119+3257, and we request an angular resolution of 0.4 arcsecond.

The CO(1-0) peak flux density of IRAS F11119+3257 measured with IRAM 30m is 25 mJy. To allow for a small fraction (~30%) of extended emission that might be missed by long baseline observations and ensure a sufficient S/N across the entire width of the line for the detection of weak broad line wing, we need to achieve an RMS of ~0.35 mJy/beam that will ensure a S/N~20 at the peak of CO line in the assumption that CO emitting region extend to 2-3 beams. The CO(1-0) line width (FWHM) of IRAS F11119+3257 is 290 km/s, and we use a bandwidth of 50 km/s for sensitivity calculation.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: IRAS 11598-0112
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Resolving out the CO(1-0) emission in IRAS 11598-0112

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: The line width (FWHM) of IRAS 11598-0112 is 210 km/s, we will further smooth the channel width to 35 km/s.

We expect to resolve out the CO(1-0) emission in IRAS 11598-0112. Previous PdBI observations show that the molecular gas of IR QSOs concentrate in the nuclear 1 kpc region. The physical scale of 1 arcsecond is 2.6 kpc for IRAS 11598-0112, and we request an angular resolution of 0.4 arcsecond.

The CO(1-0) peak flux density of IRAS 11598-0112 measured with IRAM 30m is 55 mJy. To allow for a small fraction (~30%) of extended emission that might be missed by long baseline observations and ensure a sufficient S/N across the entire width of the line for the detection of weak broad line wing, we need to achieve an RMS of ~0.77 mJy/beam that will ensure a S/N>20 at the peak of CO line in the assumption that CO emitting region extend to 2-3 beams. The CO(1-0) line width (FWHM) of IRAS 11598-0112 is 210 km/s, and we use a bandwidth of 35 km/s for sensitivity calculation.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: IRAS F15069+1808
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Resolving out the CO(1-0) emission in IRAS F15069+1808

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: The line width (FWHM) of IRAS F15069+1808 is 290 km/s, we will further smooth the channel width to 50 km/s.

We expect to resolve out the CO(1-0) emission in IRAS F15069+1808. Previous PdBI observations show that the molecular gas of IR QSOs concentrate in the nuclear 1 kpc region. The physical scale of 1 arcsecond is 2.9 kpc for IRAS F15069+1808, and we request an angular resolution of 0.4 arcsecond.

The CO(1-0) peak flux density of IRAS F15069+1808 measured with IRAM 30m is 33 mJy. Allowing for a small fraction (~30%) of extended emission that might be missed by long baseline observations, we need to achieve an RMS of ~0.58 mJy/beam that will ensure a S/N~10 at the peak of CO line in the assumption that CO emitting region extend to ~4 beams. The CO(1-0) line width (FWHM) of IRAS F15069+1808 is 290 km/s, and we use a bandwidth of 50 km/s for sensitivity calculation.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: IRAS F15462-0450
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Resolving out the CO(1-0) emission in IRAS F15462-0450

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: The line width (FWHM) of IRAS F15462-0450 is 210 km/s, we will further smooth the channel width to 35 km/s.

We expect to resolve out the CO(1-0) emission in IRAS F15462-0450. Previous PdBI observations show that the molecular gas of IR QSOs concentrate in the nuclear 1 kpc region. The physical scale of 1 arcsecond is 1.9 kpc for IRAS F15462-0450, and thus we request an angular resolution of 0.4 arcsecond.

The CO(1-0) peak flux density of IRAS F15462-0450 measured with IRAM 30m is 42 mJy. To allow for a small fraction (~30%) of extended emission that might be missed by long baseline observations and ensure a sufficient S/N across the entire width of the line for the detection of weak broad line wing, we need to achieve an RMS of ~0.59 mJy/beam that will ensure a S/N~20 at the peak of CO line in the assumption that CO emitting region extend to 2-3 beams. The CO(1-0) line width (FWHM) of IRAS F15462-0450 is 210 km/s, and we use a bandwidth of 35 km/s for sensitivity calculation. Since IRAS F15462-0450 is not very far away from IRAS F15069+1808, it is possible that we can share both flux and bandpass calibrators for these two galaxies, and in this case we will save about 7.5 minutes of observing time.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: IRAS F22454-1744
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Resolving out the CO(1-0) emission in IRAS F22454-1744

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: The line width (FWHM) of IRAS F22454-1744 is 190 km/s, we will further smooth the channel width to 30 km/s.

We expect to resolve out the CO(1-0) emission in IRAS F22454-1744. Previous PdBI observations show that the molecular gas of IR QSOs is concentrated in the nuclear 1 kpc region. The physical scale of 1 arcsecond is 2.1 kpc for IRAS F22454-1744, and we request an angular resolution of 0.4 arcsecond for resolving.

The CO(1-0) peak flux density of IRAS F22454-1744 mesured with the IRAM 30m is 55 mJy. Allowing for a small fraction (~30%) of extended emission that might be missed by long baseline observations, we need to achieve an RMS of ~0.77 mJy/beam that will ensure a S/N~10 at the peak of CO line in the assumption that CO emitting region extend to ~5 beams. The CO(1-0) line width (FWHM) of IRAS F22454-1744 is 190 km/s, and we use a bandwidth of 30 km/s for sensitivity calculation.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: IRAS F23411+0228
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Resolving out the CO(1-0) emission in IRAS F23411+0228

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: The line width (FWHM) of IRAS F23411+0228 is 220 km/s, we will further smooth the channel width to 35 km/s.

We expect to resolve out the CO(1-0) emission in IRAS F23411+0228. Previous PdBI observations show that the molecular gas of IR QSOs concentrate in the nuclear 1 kpc region. The physical scale of 1 arcsecond is 1.7 kpc for IRAS F23411+0228, and thus we request an angular resolution of 0.4 arcsecond.

The CO(1-0) peak flux density of IRAS F23411+0228 measured with IRAM 30m is 32 mJy. Allowing for a small fraction (~30%) of extended emission that might be missed by long baseline observations, we need to achieve an RMS of ~0.56 mJy/beam that will ensure a S/N~10 at the peak of CO line in the assumption that CO emitting region extend to ~4 beams. The CO(1-0) line width (FWHM) of IRAS F23411+0228 is 220 km/s, and we use a bandwidth of 35 km/s for sensitivity calculation. Since IRAS F23411+0228 is not very far away from IRAS F22454-1744 and I ZW 1, it is possible that we can share both flux and bandpass calibrators for either F23411 and F22454 or F23411 and I ZW 1, and in this case we will save about 7.5 minutes of observing time.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: CO survey of the host galaxies of ultraluminous infrared QSOs (IR QSOs) reveals a massive reservoir of molecular gas and confirms that the FIR emission of IR QSOs are mainly from star formation (SF). We propose to map 8 IR QSOs at z=0.061-0.190 showing the strongest CO emission to study the distribution and kinematics of molecular gas on sub-kpc scale with the ALMA. This will be the first attempt to systematically probe the ~1 kpc nuclear regions of IR QSOs where SF/AGN activities play important roles in shaping up the galaxy evolution (once combining with few nearest IR QSOs that have been imaged in CO, e.g., MrK 231). With the accurate measurements of CO size and kinematics, we can study the M_BH-M_bulge relation and the kinematic signature of molecular gas around black holes in the IR QSO phase. The high resolution ALMA observations will also enable us to resolve the size and geometry of molecular outflows in the hosts of IR QSOs. Together with the multi-wavelength studies of local ULIRGs and PG QSOs, the systematic studies of IR QSOs will help us better understand the co-evolution of starbursts and AGNs as well as provide the best examined local analogues to those at high-z.

prp:PrincipalInvestigator.prp:organisation: School of Science, The University of Tokyo
